data.question: What are the main materials synthesized in the study for photocatalytic CO2 reduction?
data.answer: TMOF-10-NH2(I) and TMOF-10-NH2(Br)

data.question: What is the role of perchloric acid in the synthesis of TMOF-10-NH2?
data.answer: Perchloric acid acts as an inorganic acid to regulate the synthetic pH and as a crystallization stabilizer.

data.question: How were the Ru nanoparticles synthesized?
data.answer: By thermal decomposition of Ru3(CO)12 in tri-n-octylamine (TOA).

data.question: What method was used to measure the apparent quantum yield (AQY) for CO2-to-CO conversion?
data.answer: The AQY was measured under specific excitation wavelength with a band pass filter, using a 300 W Xe lamp.

data.question: Is the photocatalytic activity of Ru@TMOF-10-NH2 higher than that of other lead halide perovskites and amino-functionalized metal-oxo MOFs?
data.answer: Yes, the photocatalytic activity for Ru@TMOF-10-NH2 is higher than all of the previous reported lead halide perovskites as well as many amino-functionalized pristine metal-oxo MOFs.

data.question: What is the main product of photocatalytic CO2 reduction in the study?
data.answer: CO

data.question: What technique was used to confirm the production and accumulation of H2O2 during the photocatalytic process?
data.answer: Quantified by colorimetry and DPD/POD methods.

data.question: Did the study find any Pb2+ leaching problem during the photocatalytic reaction?
data.answer: No, no Pb2+ leaching problem was noticed to cause environmental problems.

data.question: What was the role of ultrasmall noble metal nanoparticles in the study?
data.answer: They acted as cocatalysts to suppress the electron-hole recombination and enhance photocatalytic conversion efficiency.

data.question: What method was used to study the carrier-transport characteristics of the synthesized materials?
data.answer: Surface photovoltage spectroscopy (SPV), ultrafast transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy, and Hall effect measurement.

data.question: Was the photocatalytic performance of TMOF-10-NH2 superior to conventional benchmark metal-oxo MOFs?
data.answer: Yes

data.question: What was the main challenge addressed by synthesizing TMOF-10-NH2 materials?
data.answer: The insufficiency of chemical stability of many metal halide hybrids in the presence of water, limiting their photocatalytic applications.

data.question: How was the stability of TMOF-10-NH2 materials tested?
data.answer: Through thermogravimetric analysis, ex-situ thermodiffraction, and incubation under different humidity conditions.

data.question: What was the main advantage of using TMOF-10-NH2 materials for photocatalytic CO2 reduction?
data.answer: Their combination of MOF-based porosity for gas-phase reaction and lead perovskitoid-based photocarrier-transport properties.

data.question: Did the study propose a mechanism for the photocatalytic CO2 reduction process?
data.answer: Yes, involving the adsorption of CO2 and H2O, formation of *COOH intermediates, and subsequent reduction to CO.

data.question: Was the photocatalytic activity of TMOF-10-NH2 materials enhanced by loading with Ru nanoparticles?
data.answer: Yes, nearly 2-fold enhancement in photocatalytic CO2 reduction was observed.

data.question: What was the main product of water oxidation during the photocatalytic process?
data.answer: H2O2

data.question: Did the study perform any control experiments to verify the origin of carbon production?
data.answer: Yes, including control photocatalytic experiments without photocatalysts or in the dark, and a 13CO2 labeling experiment.

data.question: What was the role of in situ DRIFTS measurement in the study?
data.answer: To understand the CO2 photoreduction process occurring on TMOF-10-NH2(I) by identifying intermediate species.

data.question: Was the photocatalytic CO2 reduction process thermodynamically favorable according to Gibbs free energy calculations?
data.answer: Yes, indicating that the CO2 adsorption and activation on TMOF-10-NH2(I) is energy-favorable.
